Chapter 9: Revealing the Nature of Emptiness Again (5) The Sutra of the Golden Light, Most Victorious King, Chapter 9: Revealing the Nature of Emptiness Again At that time, after the World-Honored One had spoken this mantra, in order to benefit the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas and the great assembly of humans and devas, to enable them to understand the profound true ultimate truth, he again revealed the nature of emptiness and spoke a verse, saying:
I have already extensively explained the profound and subtle Dharma of emptiness in other very profound sutras;
Now, within this king of sutras, I will briefly explain the inconceivable Dharma of emptiness.
In the vast and profound Dharma, sentient beings lack wisdom and are unable to understand;
Therefore, I will now elaborate on it again, enabling them to gain insight into the Dharma of emptiness.
Out of great compassion and pity for sentient beings, using skillful means and excellent causes and conditions;
I will now explain it in this great assembly, enabling them to understand the meaning of emptiness.
One should know that this body is like an empty village, with six thieves relying on each other without knowing each other;
The six dust thieves rely on the faculties individually, not knowing each other, it is also like this.
The eye faculty always observes the realm of forms, the ear faculty listens to sounds without interruption;
The nose faculty always smells fragrant objects, the tongue faculty constantly tastes delicious flavors,
The body faculty experiences light and soft touch, the mind faculty cognizes dharmas without knowing satiety,
These six faculties arise according to their functions, each producing discrimination towards its own objects.
Consciousness is like an illusion, not real, relying on the faculties and places to falsely crave;
Like a person running in an empty town, the six consciousnesses relying on the faculties are also like this.
The mind roams everywhere, turning according to the place, relying on the faculties to cognize various things;
Always loving form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, seeking dharmas without a moment's rest.
Following conditions, it universally functions in the six faculties, like a bird flying in the sky without obstruction;
Relying on these faculties as a basis, it is able to cognize external objects.
This body is without knowledge and without an agent, its substance is not solid, relying on conditions to form;
All arise from false discrimination, like a machine turning due to karma.
Earth, water, fire, and wind together form the body, following those causes and conditions to invite different results;
Being in the same place, they are mutually harmful, like four poisonous snakes living in one basket.
The natures of these four great snakes are different, although they dwell in one place, there is rising and sinking;
Sometimes above, sometimes below, pervading the body, these will eventually return to the dharma of cessation.
Among these four poisonous snakes, the two snakes of earth and water mostly sink down;
The two snakes of wind and fire are by nature light and buoyant, and from this discrepancy, various illnesses arise.
The mind and consciousness rely on this body, creating various good and evil karma;
One will go to the realms of humans, gods, or the three evil destinies, according to the power of one's karma, one will receive a physical form.
Encountering various illnesses, after the body dies, excrement and urine overflow everywhere;
Putrid, infested with maggots, and unpleasant, abandoned in the charnel ground like rotten wood.
You should contemplate the Dharma in this way - how can one grasp at the existence of a self and sentient beings?
All dharmas are impermanent, all arise from the power of causes and conditions.
Those great elements are all false, originally not truly existent, without a nature of arising;
Therefore, it is said that the nature of the great elements is all empty, knowing that this floating and illusory is not truly existent.

Chapter 10: Relying on Emptiness to Fulfill Wishes (5) The Sutra of the Golden Light, Most Victorious King, Chapter 10: Relying on Emptiness to Fulfill Wishes At that time, the celestial maiden Wish-Fulfilling Jewel Light, hearing the profound Dharma in the great assembly, joyfully leapt up, rose from her seat, bared her right shoulder, touched her right knee to the ground, joined her palms in respect, and said to the Buddha:

At that time, the celestial maiden requested the World-Honored One, saying:
How do the Bodhisattvas practice the correct practice of Bodhi?
And benefit oneself and others?
The Buddha said to the Goddess:
Relying on the Dharma realm, practicing the Dharma of enlightenment, cultivating impartial conduct.
How does one rely on the Dharma realm, practice the Dharma of enlightenment, and cultivate impartial conduct?

It means that the five aggregates can manifest the Dharma realm, the Dharma realm is precisely the five aggregates, the five aggregates cannot be spoken of, and the non-five aggregates also cannot be spoken of.
Why is this?
If the Dharma realm is the five aggregates, it is the view of annihilation;
If apart from the five aggregates, it is the view of permanence;
Apart from the two characteristics, not attached to the two extremes, invisible, beyond what is seen, nameless and formless, this is called speaking of the Dharma realm.
Goddess!
How can the five aggregates manifest the Dharma realm?
Such five aggregates are not born from causes and conditions.
Why is this?
If born from causes and conditions, is it born because it has already arisen?
Is it produced for the sake of what has not yet arisen?
If what has already arisen is produced, what is the use of causes and conditions?
If what has not yet arisen is produced, it cannot be produced.
Why is this?
All dharmas that have not yet arisen are non-existent, without name or form, beyond comparison or metaphor, and not produced by causes and conditions.
Good woman!
It is like the sound of a drum, which arises based on wood, skin, and the beating of hands. Thus, the sound of the drum is empty in the past, empty in the future, and empty in the present.
Why is this?
The sound of the drum does not arise from the wood, does not arise from the skin or the beating of hands, and does not arise in the three times. It is then unproduced.
If it cannot be produced, then it cannot cease;
if it cannot cease, then it does not come from anywhere;
if it does not come from anywhere, then it does not go anywhere;
if it does not go anywhere, then it is neither eternal nor annihilated;
If it is neither permanent nor annihilated, then it is neither the same nor different.
Why is this?
If it is the same, then it is not different from the Dharma realm.
If it were so, then ordinary people would see the truth and attain the unsurpassed peace and bliss of nirvana;
Since it is not so, therefore it is known to be not the same.

If it is said to be different, then the characteristics of the practices of all Buddhas and Bodhisattvas would be clinging, and they would not be liberated from the bonds of afflictions, and would not realize supreme perfect enlightenment.
Why is this?
Because all sages and ordinary beings share the same true nature in their practices and non-practices, therefore they are not different.

Therefore, know that the five aggregates are neither existent nor non-existent, are not born from causes and conditions, and are not born without causes and conditions. This is known by the sages and is not the realm of others, and is also not accessible to words. It is without name, without characteristics, without causes, without conditions, and without analogies. From beginning to end, it is tranquil and originally self-empty.
Therefore, the five aggregates can manifest the Dharma realm.

It is like a magician or the disciple of a magician who is skilled in magic arts. If there are sentient beings who are foolish and ignorant, unable to contemplate, and do not understand the basis of the magic, if they see or hear [the magic], they think like this:

Afterwards, they do not further examine and contemplate.
A wise person is not like this. Understanding the basis of the magic, if they see or hear [the magic], they think like this:

What I see, the multitudes of elephants, horses, and so forth, is not real. There is only the magic, deceiving people's eyes, falsely calling them elephants and so forth, and various granaries. There is a name but no reality. As I see and hear, I do not grasp it as real.
Later, reflecting on it, he knew it was false.

Therefore, the wise understand that all dharmas are without real substance, but in accordance with worldly convention, they see and hear as they do, and proclaim the matter as they see it. Reflecting on the truth, it is not like this. Moreover, it is because of provisional explanations that the true meaning is revealed.

Foolish ordinary beings, not yet having attained the supramundane wisdom-eye of the sages, do not yet know that the suchness of all dharmas is inexpressible.

These foolish ordinary beings, whether seeing or hearing of practiced and non-practiced dharmas, reflect in this way and give rise to attachment, considering them to be real. They are unable to understand in the ultimate truth that the suchness of dharmas is inexpressible.

These sages, whether seeing or hearing of dharmas that are practiced or not practiced, according to their ability do not give rise to attachment, considering them to be truly existent. They understand that all dharmas that are practiced or not practiced are not real, but are only false conceptualizations of the characteristics of practice and non-practice, with only names and no real substance.
These sages speak in accordance with worldly conventions, wishing to cause others to know the true meaning.

These sages, with their holy wisdom and insight, understand the thusness of dharmas that cannot be spoken of. Therefore, dharmas that are practiced or not practiced are also like this. In order to cause others to realize and know, they speak various worldly names and words.
At that time, the Great Brahma King asked Wish-Fulfilling Jewel Light-Illumination Bodhisattva, saying:
